pgTitle: List of New York State Historic Markers in Dutchess County, New York

rows.text: NYS 343, Northest of Leedsville, at NY-CT Line.
Created In 1638, And Named For The Dutchess Of York. The "t" In Original Name Is Still Used.
Named From The Latin "amoena," "pleasant To The Eye," By Dr. Thomas Young, Early Settler, Who Also Named Vermont.
NYS 343, Northeast of Leedsville, At NY-CT Line.
Explored By Dutch, 1609, Settled By Dutch, 1624;k. Under English Rule After 1664. Named For Duke Of York, Later King James II.
Fist Settler Of Amenia, About 1711, Had Farm Here And Is Buried On Hill To North. He Was Commissioner On Palatine Settlement.
Built In 1835; It Was Directed By The Methodist Church. It Had A High Reputation And Many Noted Graduates.
County Road 0.5 miles Northwest of Amenia Union.
Uldrick Winegar And His Son Capt. Garrett Winegar, Who Came From The East Camp Of The Palatines, Germantown, N.Y. Settled Here In 1724.
Incorporated May 15, 1913 Consolidation Of Mattewan And Fishkill Landing Villages.
Incorporated May 15, 1913 Consolidation Of Mattewan And Fishkill Landing Villages.
Incorporated May 15, 1913 Consolidation Of Mattewan And Fishkill Landing Villages.
In 1869 Pop. 1100; Contained 4 Churches, Newspaper Office, Steamboat Landing, 2 Machine Shops, R.R. Station. Steam Ferry To Newburgh. Ferry In 1743.
In 1869 Pop. 1100; Contained 4 Churches, Newspaper Office, Steamboat Landing, 2 Machine Shops, R.R. Station. Steam Ferry To Newburgh. Ferry In 1743.
One Of Oldest Landings Along Hudson River. During Rev. Supplies For Troops In Newburgh & N.j. From New England Brought Across River.
In 1860 Pop. 1476, Contained 4 Churches, Machine Works, Clothing And File Factories, And Rubber Shop. Formerly Had Extensive Cotton Mills.
NYS 9d, at foot of Mount Beacon.
On The Summit, 1640 Feet Above Hudson, Was One Of System Of Beacon In The Highlands Planned By Gens. Washington And Clinton.
NYS 22, North of NYS 55, at Wingdale.
NYS 22, North of NYS 55, at Wingdale.
Rode Horseback Over This Road The Night Of April 26, 1777, To Call Out Colonel Ludington's Regiment To Repel British At Danbury, Conn.
County Road, 1 mile West of Pecksville, at Dutchess-Putnam County Line.
East Fishkill, Dutchess Co. Formed From Fishkill 1849. Kent, Putnam Co. Formed As Frederickstown 1788. Changed To Frederick 1795, Kent 1817.
NYS 52, 0.5 miles South of Pecksville, at Dutchess-Putnam County Line.
East Fishkill, Dutchess Co. Formed From Fishkill 1849. Kent, Putnam Co. Formed As Frederickstown 1788. Changed To Frederick 1795, Kent 1817.
East Fishkill Formed From Fishkill 1849. Fishkill Formed 1788. Part Of La Grange Off 1821 And East Fishkill 1849. Part Of Philipstown Annexed 1806.
East Fishkill Formed From Fishkill 1849. Fishkill Formed 1788. Part Of La Grange Off 1821 And East Fishkill 1849. Part Of Philipstown Annexed 1806.
East Fishkill Formed From Fishkill 1849. Beekman Formed As Town 1788. Part Of Lagrange Off In 1821: And Part Of Union Vale In 1827.
US 9, 1/8 mile North of Dutchess-Putnam County Line.
On This Hill, During The American Revolution, Was A Battery For The Defense Of "the Gorge Of The Mountains," Fishkill Clove.
Built 1738 By Colonel John Brinckerhoff Washington's Headquarters While Army Was In Fishkill.
Created In 1683 And Named For The Dutchess Of York. The "t" In Original Name Is Still Used.
American Spy, Taken With Recruits For British Army, Confined Here After Mock Trial By Committee Of Safety Was Allowed To Escape.
Built 1753. Fishkill Headquarters Of Baron Von Steuben About 1777. Gen. Washington And Count Pulaski Visited Here.
Built By Abram Brinckerhoff. Burned 1777. Rebuilt By Order Of Gen. Washington While His Soldiers Encamped At Fishkill. Later Demolished.
Built 1740, By Gulian Verplanck, Burned 1931. Headquarters Baron Steuben 1762. Society Of Cincinnati Organized There In 1783.
Made Famous By Cooper's Novel, "The Spy" Headquarters Of Gen. Putnam In Revolution.
Was Forged Or Repaired Near Here By John Bailey. The Sword Is Now In Smithsonian Museum, Washington, D.C.
Reformed Church Of Fishkill Organized 1716, Built 1725, Occupied 1776 By New York Provincial Congress, Also Prison During Revolution.
US 9, 2 miles North of Hyde Park.
US 9, 1 mile North of Hyde Park.
Site Erected 1844. Attended By Franklin D. Roosevelt, 32d President Of The United States, And His Family.
Old Name Of Community One Mile East, With Meeting House Of Society Of Friends, 18th Century Center For A Wide Neighborhood.
County Road, West of Jackson Corners.
Chief Crow And Other Mohican Shacomecos Of Moravian Faith Buried Here. Last Burial About 1850.
Built About 1773 Stage Inn, Doctor's Office, Hotel, Store, Post Office Of Jackson Corners.
County Road, between Upper Red Hook and Jackson Corners.
John Fulton, First Owner. Deed Recorded Oct. 12, 1795 Has Always Been In Possession Of The Fulton Family. In Fulton Name Until 1933.
County Road, West of Jackson Corners.
Running From Post Road In Livingston, Through Gallatin, Ancram, State Line, Nobletown, To Barrington, N.H. In Use Before 1798.
Burying Ground Private Grave Yard Old Stone 1825.
0.5 mile East of US 44, at Coleman's Station.
Burying Ground Private Grave Yard Old Stone 1749.
Irondale, Millerton. Town Of North East Old Stone 1818.hip, Litchfield.
County Road, 1.5 miles East of NYS 22
Burying Ground Belonged To Baptist Church. Land Donated Here For Church & Grave Yard By Rev. Simon Dakin, 1776. Oldest Stone 1701.
County Road, 1.5 miles East of Irondale.
North East Post Office May 1, 1773, First Baptist Covenant Meeting In North East Held At Home Of Rev. Simon Dakin, Near Here.
North East Township, Dutchess County, New York State; Salisbury Township, Litchfield County, Connecticut.
North East Township, Dutchess County, New York State; Salisbury Township, Litchfield County, Connecticut.
Created In 1683 And Named For The Dutchess Of York. The "t" In Original Name Is Still Used.
Commander Of The Monitor, Against The Confederate Ram, Merrimac, Hampton Roads, Mar.9, 1862; Rear Admiral, U.s.n. Is Buried Here.
NYS 199, 2 Mis. W. Of Pine Plains
West Pine Plains Dedicated 1859 By Rev. Ali Fay Of Yellow Springs, Ohio. New Storehouse For Farm Machinery And Also Garage.
NYS 199, .5 Mi. W. Of Pine Plains
Named For Mr. Hubbell Who Built Cabin Nearby About 1760. Watering Through Here Since That Date.
Named For Captain Thomas Ross, Who Was Called "Baron Ross" Died August, 1762.
NYS 199, .5 Mi. E. Of Pine Plains
Rhinebeck-Salisbury Turnpike. Legislative Act Passed April 2, 1802.
NYS 82, 4 Mis. Se Of Pine Plains
Northeast Line Ine Plains Organized 1823. Northeast Formed 1788 And Included Milan And Pine Plains. Milan Taken Off In 1818.
NYS 199, At Pine Plains-north East Line
Northeast Line Pine Plains Organied 1823. Northeast Formed 1788 And Included Milan And Pine Plains. Milan Taken Off In 1818.
NYS 82 A, 1 Mi, N. Of Attlebury, At Pine Plains-Stanford Line
Pine Plains Organized 1823. Part Of Northeast 1788 And Little Nine Partners 1706. Stanford Organized 1793. Part Of Washington 1788 And Great Nine Partners 1697.
Stone From Here Used In Basement Walls Of Addition To Presbyterian Church; Also For Foundations In Evergreen Cemetery.
Built About 1728. Repaired Before 1775 And Top Story Added. J. Lewis, Storekeeper, 1st Occupant. Indian Trading Post And Store. Torn Down 1878.
SE Corner Main And Church Sts. In Pine Plains
Log House Tavern Inn 1798, Dr. Asahel Haskins, Prop. Hotel Built 1804 By F. & E. Dibblee, C. Ketterer Owner Enlarged Hotel 1872 & 1882.
Academy And Smith Sts., In Pine Plains
Site Of Seymour Smith Academy Opened 1879: Leased 1896, As Union Free School. Rev. A. Mattice, A.m. Only Principal.
NYS 82, 3 Mis. Se Of Pine Plains
Site Of Red Church Built By German Reformers 1772 On Pulver Farm; Torn Down 1826; Known As The Old Red Church.
SW Corner Main And Church Sts. In Pine Plains.
Union Library Of Pine Plains Organized 1798. Ebenezer Baldwin First Librarian. First Public Library In Town Of North East.
Founder Of Vassar College, Lived In House On This Site For Many Years. Now Site Of Vassar Bros. Home.
On This Site 1777-1807 Stephen Hendrickson's Inn; 1807-1876, The Forbus House; Since 1876, The Nelson House.
First Settlers In 1687. New York State Capital, 1778-1783. Constitution Of The United States Ratified Here By New York, July 26, 1788.
First Settlers In 1687. New York State Capital, 1778-1783. Constitution Of The United States Ratified Here By New York, July 26, 1788.
First Settlers In 1687. New York State Capital, 1778-1783. Constitution Of The United States Ratified Here By New York, July 26, 1788.
US 9, 75 Yds. N. Of City Line
Site Of Smith Thompson Country Home Thompson Was Secretary Of Navy, 1818-1822 And Justice Of The Supreme Court Of U.s., 1833-1843.
Built In 1767 By Members Of The Church Of England In Dutchess County For Their Minister.
Dutch Name For "Stream of Falls" "Pondanickrien" Is The Indian Name Meaning "Crooked Place".
NE Corner Livingston And Prospect Sts.
On Shore Line Of River Was A Continental Shipyard Where Frigates Congress And Montgomery Were Built To Defend The Hudson River
Shaefe Rd., At N.y. Trap Rock Co.
Entrance To Estate Owned And Occupied 1804-1812 By George Clinton Then Vice President Of The United States.
Dutch For "speck, His Stream". Later Called Speck'n Kill And Speckenkill. Speck, An Indian, Owed This Land.
County Court Judge, Colonel Of Militia, Member Council Of Safety, Constitutional Convention, Delegate State Senate Lived Here 1762-1798.
W. Market & Phillips Sts., In Red Hook
Built Brick House Here Before 1797. Was Captain During Revolution, Gen. Of State Militia, State Senator And Presidential Elector 1812.
US 9, .5 Mi. N. Of Kerleys Corners
Created In 1683 And Named For The Dutchess Of York. The "t" In Original Name Is Still Used.
E. Of US 9, In Upper Red Hook
Known In 1789 As The Thomas House Headquarters In 1777 Of General Putnam.
Birthplace Of Brig. Gen. John A. Quitman Sept. 1, 1799-July 17, 1858 Hero Of Mexican War Senator, Chancellor, Judge Governor Of Mississippi
House Occupied By Gen. Richard Montgomery When He Took Command Of The Northern Forces 1775.
Landing For Ferry Chartered 1752, Connecting The Ulster As Salisbury Pike On The East With The Ulster And Delaware On The West.
Original Location Of The Village Of Rhinebeck Site Of Oldest Church In Northern Precinct Of Dutchess County.
NYS 308, E. Of Mulberry St., In Rhinebeck
Built About 1800 Known Also As "Bowery House" Was Social Center Of Community; Its Courtroom, Theater & Ballroom Was Hdqts. "Yellow Bird" Stage Line.
Ruins Of The Kip-Beekman-Heermance House Built 1700 By Hendrick Kip, Patentee. Home Of Col. Henry Beekman, Jr. Later Of His Grandson Col. Henry B. Livingston Of The Rev. Army.
Westward On The Left (right) Gasmere-birthplace-W.A. Duer Once President Of Columbia Col. On The Right Beyond - Ellerslie Home Of Levi P. Morton, Gov. Of N.Y. & Vice Pres. Of U.S.
NW Corner Mill & W. Market Sts. In Rhinebeck
Built In 1816 By Christian Schell. Once The Commercial And Financial Center Of The Community.
Pre-Revolutionary House Home Of Mesier Family From 1777 To 1890 Acquired By Village 1891.
Jacob Willetts Deborah Willetts Widely Known Educators Lived Here In Early 19th Century.
On This Site, 1796-1863, Influential In Education Famous For Its Teachers And Pupils
